posts.name: David Lame
posts.cooked:
I am finding much grief with a swerveDrivePoseEstimator.  I am hoping there is an obvious flaw that I can’t see.

I have this snippet of code that runs in robotPeriodic:

public static Pose2d updatePoseWithOdometry() { Rotation2d currentAngle=new Rotation2d(Devices.yawSensor.getYawRadians()); Pose2d prePose=poseEstimator.getEstimatedPosition(); System.out.println("Preupdate x: “+prePose.getX()+” yaw “+prePose.getRotation().getDegrees() +” Pigeon angle: " +currentAngle.getDegrees()); Pose2d currentPose= poseEstimator.update(currentAngle, SwerveModule.getPositions()); System.out.println("Pose in odometry x: “+currentPose.getX()+” yaw: "+currentPose.getRotation().getDegrees()); return currentPose; }

Devices.yawSensor is a wrapper around a Pigeon.  (We have robots with a Pigeon, and with a NavX.  The wrapper allows us to use them interchangeably.)

We are using PathPlanner.  At the beginniing of autonomous, we call reset on our poseEstimator  (i.e. an instance of SwerveDrivePoseEstimator). That seems to work fine.

Then, on the first update after autonomousInit, we get these lines printed: Preupdate x: 7.2372435897435885 yaw -90.0 Pigeon angle: -90.0 Pose in odometry x: 7.2372435897435885 yaw: -0.008239746093761999

Since the two printn statements are immediately before and immediately after the update statement, any change has to be the result of the update.

Prior to autonomousInit, the estimated position is x=0, y=0 yaw = 0.  The values above (i.e. x=7.2…, yaw = -90, y is not shown) come from the PathPlanner path definition.

This change to approximately 0 in the estimated rotation (i.e. yaw) of the robot only happens once.  If I disable autonomous, and run it a second time, the correct yaw will be shown after autonomousInit, and it will go in the correct direction.  The consequence is that we go in the wrong direction, once.  The second and subsequent times, it works fine.

If only the referees would allow us to run our autonomous program on the field once when we turn on the robot, we would be in great shape.

And…of course…it didn’t do this at the last competition and “we didn’t change anything that should make a difference”, i.e. we obviously must have changed something, but I’ve examined all the changes and I can’t see anything that should cause problems.  We edited the path, and we have some changes at the end of the program, but the start seems to be the same.

Is there an obvious explanatiion?

posts.name: David Lame
posts.cooked:
Update:  I “fixed” the problem with the following code:

Pose2d prePose=poseEstimator.getEstimatedPosition(); System.out.println("Preupdate x: “+prePose.getX()+” yaw “+prePose.getRotation().getDegrees() +” Pigeon angle: " +currentAngle.getDegrees()); Pose2d currentPose= poseEstimator.update(currentAngle, SwerveModule.getPositions()); if (Math.abs(prePose.getRotation().getDegrees()-currentPose.getRotation().getDegrees())>45.0) { poseEstimator.resetPose(prePose); return prePose; }

In other words, if the update causes more than a 45 degree change in pose, ignore the update and reset it to the pre-update value.

That seems kind of messed up, but it’s working.

I have a feeling that there’s somethiing wrong with the way I’m initializing the poseEstimator, or possibly that it has some grief if it sits for a long time processing odometry values when the speed is zero.

ETA:  It occurs to me I could have some grief at + or - 180.  I can fix that.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
David_Lame:

If I disable autonomous, and run it a second time

If you do this, then you have not gone through the power-on sequence that resets the gyro to zero as the direction it happens to be pointing at the time (assuming that’s what your Pigeon setting is) and you have not gone through the Robot constructor and all the rest of your initializing code especially making sure the gyro is reset to your actual starting position.

The system is more complicated that you reveal. PathPlanner has your pose update and reset.  PP also has the option that you promise or not that the robot is poised as required for the start of the path.

Lots to verify is happening including understanding how you put your robot on the field then turn it on.

It’s always tempting to just disable and re-enable to rerun tests but that is not realistic; even restart robot code isn’t fully realistic as that doesn’t perform the power-on resets of all your devices and sensors (especially the gyro).

If disable/enable produces different results than restart robot code or power-on then you are missing code in your disable or periodic init methods that would be needed to exactly replicate the restart robot code.  Better yet, probably, is use restart robot instead of enable/disable. If the robot isn’t right doing that, then troubleshoot that without band-aids.

posts.name: David Lame
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

PathPlanner has your pose update and reset. PP also has the option that you promise or not that the robot is poised as required for the start of the path.

This part seems like a possible culprit.

I’m not aware of it, so I’m not doing anything about it.  (It’s possible the student who actually wrote the PathPlanner related code knows about it.  I’ll ask him when  I see him tonight.  I was doing troubleshooting on it to try and uncover the error.)

The Pigeon reading is being reset, and has the proper value at the time that the failed update command is processed, so I’m not terribly concerned about that part.  The devices, i.e. gyroscope, wheel encoders, absolute and relative, are all giving all the right answers.  It’s just that one failed update where the problem comes in.

This is the first year we have used PathPlanner, so there is almost certainly a rookie mistake going on.  Our off-season agenda involves going a lot more deep with the capabilities and making sure we are using it correctly, but the robot is getting loaded into a trailer tonight for competition tomorrow, so I think band-aids are the order of the day.

But  I will be happy if I ever figure out the actual source of the error.

posts.name: John Slagel
posts.cooked:
I don’t know if this helps, but here is our DriveSubsystem (using MaxSwerve and Pigeon, no Limelight odometry) that works well with autonomous PathPlanner. This tries to make the field oriented drive work correctly based on the PathPlanner “promised starting positions” and doesn’t reset the Pigeon heading to 0 to reset field oriented drive, see resetFieldOrientedDir .  Hopefully this will give you some ideas.  Play close attention to the setEstimatedPose function.

DriveSubsystem.java (15.7 KB)

posts.name: David Lame
posts.cooked:
Thanks.  The biggest difference I see is the “updateWithTime()” function, where we just have update().  But looking at the source code, update() calls updateWithTime(), using MathStore.getTimeStamp().

I have no idea what MathStore.getTimeStamp() does.

Of course our code is arranged differently, but all the same calls are being made, except for that timestamp issue.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
David_Lame:

I have no idea what MathStore.getTimeStamp() does.

It gets the current timestamp—it’s mapped to Timer.getTimestamp() by RobotBase.
